M1036.name: Account Use Policies
M1036.description: Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.

M1015.name: Active Directory Configuration
M1015.description: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

M1049.name: Antivirus/Antimalware
M1049.description: Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

M1013.name: Application Developer Guidance
M1013.description: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.

M1048.name: Application Isolation and Sandboxing
M1048.description: Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.

M1047.name: Audit
M1047.description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

M1040.name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
M1040.description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

M1046.name: Boot Integrity
M1046.description: Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.

M1045.name: Code Signing
M1045.description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

M1043.name: Credential Access Protection
M1043.description: Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

M1053.name: Data Backup
M1053.description: Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

M1057.name: Data Loss Prevention
M1057.description: Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

M1042.name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
M1042.description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

M1055.name: Do Not Mitigate
M1055.description: This category is to associate techniques that mitigation might increase risk of compromise and therefore mitigation is not recommended.

M1041.name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
M1041.description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

M1039.name: Environment Variable Permissions
M1039.description: Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.

M1038.name: Execution Prevention
M1038.description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

M1050.name: Exploit Protection
M1050.description: Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.

M1037.name: Filter Network Traffic
M1037.description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

M1035.name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
M1035.description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

M1034.name: Limit Hardware Installation
M1034.description: Block users or groups from installing or using unapproved hardware on systems, including USB devices.

M1033.name: Limit Software Installation
M1033.description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

M1032.name: Multi-factor Authentication
M1032.description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

M1031.name: Network Intrusion Prevention
M1031.description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

M1030.name: Network Segmentation
M1030.description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

M1028.name: Operating System Configuration
M1028.description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

M1027.name: Password Policies
M1027.description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

M1056.name: Pre-compromise
M1056.description: This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

M1026.name: Privileged Account Management
M1026.description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

M1025.name: Privileged Process Integrity
M1025.description: Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

M1029.name: Remote Data Storage
M1029.description: Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.

M1022.name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
M1022.description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

M1044.name: Restrict Library Loading
M1044.description: Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.

M1024.name: Restrict Registry Permissions
M1024.description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

M1021.name: Restrict Web-Based Content
M1021.description: Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.

M1054.name: Software Configuration
M1054.description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

M1020.name: SSL/TLS Inspection
M1020.description: Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.

M1019.name: Threat Intelligence Program
M1019.description: A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.

M1051.name: Update Software
M1051.description: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

M1052.name: User Account Control
M1052.description: Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.

M1018.name: User Account Management
M1018.description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

M1017.name: User Training
M1017.description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

M1016.name: Vulnerability Scanning
M1016.description: Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.

SC-16.description: Associate [Assignment: organization-defined security and privacy attributes] with information exchanged between systems and between system components.

SC-17.name: Public Key Infrastructure Certificates
SC-17.description:
a. Issue public key certificates under an [Assignment: organization-defined certificate policy] or obtain public key certificates from an approved service provider; and
 b. Include only approved trust anchors in trust stores or certificate stores managed by the organization.

SC-18.name: Mobile Code
SC-18.description:
a. Define acceptable and unacceptable mobile code and mobile code technologies; and
 b. Authorize, monitor, and control the use of mobile code within the system.

SC-19.name: Voice Over Internet Protocol
SC-19.description: Technology-specific; addressed as any other technology or protocol.

SC-20.name: Secure Name/address Resolution Service (authoritative Source)
SC-20.description:
a. Provide additional data origin authentication and integrity verification artifacts along with the authoritative name resolution data the system returns in response to external name/address resolution queries; and
 b. Provide the means to indicate the security status of child zones and (if the child supports secure resolution services) to enable verification of a chain of trust among parent and child domains, when operating as part of a distributed, hierarchical namespace.

SC-21.name: Secure Name/address Resolution Service (recursive or Caching Resolver)
SC-21.description: Request and perform data origin authentication and data integrity verification on the name/address resolution responses the system receives from authoritative sources.

SC-22.name: Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service
SC-22.description: Ensure the systems that collectively provide name/address resolution service for an organization are fault-tolerant and implement internal and external role separation.

SC-23.name: Session Authenticity
SC-23.description: Protect the authenticity of communications sessions.

SC-24.name: Fail in Known State
SC-24.description: Fail to a [Assignment: organization-defined known system state] for the following failures on the indicated components while preserving [Assignment: organization-defined system state information] in failure: [Assignment: list of organization-defined types of system failures on organization-defined system components].

SC-25.name: Thin Nodes
SC-25.description: Employ minimal functionality and information storage on the following system components: [Assignment: organization-defined system components].

SC-26.name: Decoys
SC-26.description: Include components within organizational systems specifically designed to be the target of malicious attacks for detecting, deflecting, and analyzing such attacks.

SC-27.name: Platform-independent Applications
SC-27.description: Include within organizational systems the following platform independent applications: [Assignment: organization-defined platform-independent applications].

SC-28.name: Protection of Information at Rest
SC-28.description: Protect the [Selection (one or more): confidentiality; integrity] of the following information at rest: [Assignment: organization-defined information at rest].

SC-29.name: Heterogeneity
SC-29.description: Employ a diverse set of information technologies for the following system components in the implementation of the system: [Assignment: organization-defined system components].

SC-30.name: Concealment and Misdirection
SC-30.description: Employ the following concealment and misdirection techniques for [Assignment: organization-defined systems] at [Assignment: organization-defined time periods] to confuse and mislead adversaries: [Assignment: organization-defined concealment and misdirection techniques].

SC-31.name: Covert Channel Analysis
SC-31.description:
a. Perform a covert channel analysis to identify those aspects of communications within the system that are potential avenues for covert [Selection (one or more): storage; timing] channels; and
 b. Estimate the maximum bandwidth of those channels.

SC-32.name: System Partitioning
SC-32.description: Partition the system into [Assignment: organization-defined system components] residing in separate [Selection: physical; logical] domains or environments based on [Assignment: organization-defined circumstances for physical or logical separation of components].

SC-34.name: Non-modifiable Executable Programs
SC-34.description:
For [Assignment: organization-defined system components], load and execute:
 a. The operating environment from hardware-enforced, read-only media; and
 b. The following applications from hardware-enforced, read-only media: [Assignment: organization-defined applications].

SC-35.name: External Malicious Code Identification
SC-35.description: Include system components that proactively seek to identify network-based malicious code or malicious websites.

SC-36.name: Distributed Processing and Storage
SC-36.description: Distribute the following processing and storage components across multiple [Selection: physical locations; logical domains]: [Assignment: organization-defined processing and storage components].

SC-37.name: Out-of-band Channels
SC-37.description: Employ the following out-of-band channels for the physical delivery or electronic transmission of [Assignment: organization-defined information, system components, or devices] to [Assignment: organization-defined individuals or systems]: [Assignment: organization-defined out-of-band channels].

SC-38.name: Operations Security
SC-38.description: Employ the following operations security controls to protect key organizational information throughout the system development life cycle: [Assignment: organization-defined operations security controls].

SC-39.name: Process Isolation
SC-39.description: Maintain a separate execution domain for each executing system process.

SC-40.name: Wireless Link Protection
SC-40.description: Protect external and internal [Assignment: organization-defined wireless links] from the following signal parameter attacks: [Assignment: organization-defined types of signal parameter attacks or references to sources for such attacks].

SC-41.name: Port and I/O Device Access
SC-41.description: [Selection: Physically; Logically] disable or remove [Assignment: organization-defined connection ports or input/output devices] on the following systems or system components: [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components].

SC-42.name: Sensor Capability and Data

SC-43.name: Usage Restrictions
SC-43.description:
a. Establish usage restrictions and implementation guidelines for the following system components: [Assignment: organization-defined system components]; and
 b. Authorize, monitor, and control the use of such components within the system.

SC-44.name: Detonation Chambers
SC-44.description: Employ a detonation chamber capability within [Assignment: organization-defined system, system component, or location].

SC-45.name: System Time Synchronization
SC-45.description: Synchronize system clocks within and between systems and system components.

SC-46.name: Cross Domain Policy Enforcement
SC-46.description: Implement a policy enforcement mechanism [Selection: physically; logically] between the physical and/or network interfaces for the connecting security domains.

SC-47.name: Alternate Communications Paths
SC-47.description: Establish [Assignment: organization-defined alternate communications paths] for system operations organizational command and control.

SC-48.name: Sensor Relocation
SC-48.description: Relocate [Assignment: organization-defined sensors and monitoring capabilities] to [Assignment: organization-defined locations] under the following conditions or circumstances: [Assignment: organization-defined conditions or circumstances].

SC-49.name: Hardware-enforced Separation and Policy Enforcement
SC-49.description: Implement hardware-enforced separation and policy enforcement mechanisms between [Assignment: organization-defined security domains].

SC-50.name: Software-enforced Separation and Policy Enforcement
SC-50.description: Implement software-enforced separation and policy enforcement mechanisms between [Assignment: organization-defined security domains].

SC-51.name: Hardware-based Protection
SC-51.description:
a. Employ hardware-based, write-protect for [Assignment: organization-defined system firmware components]; and
 b. Implement specific procedures for [Assignment: organization-defined authorized individuals] to manually disable hardware write-protect for firmware modifications and re-enable the write-protect prior to returning to operational mode.

SI-1.name: Policy and Procedures
SI-1.description:
a. Develop, document, and disseminate to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]:
 1. [Selection (one or more): organization-level; mission/business process-level; system-level] system and information integrity policy that:
 (a) Addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and
 (b) Is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; and
 2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the system and information integrity policy and the associated system and information integrity controls;
 b. Designate an [Assignment: organization-defined official] to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the system and information integrity policy and procedures; and
 c. Review and update the current system and information integrity:
 1. Policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events]; and
 2. Procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events].

SI-2.name: Flaw Remediation

SI-3.name: Malicious Code Protection

SI-4.name: System Monitoring

SI-5.name: Security Alerts, Advisories, and Directives

SI-6.name: Security and Privacy Function Verification

SI-7.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity
SI-7.description:
a. Employ integrity verification tools to detect unauthorized changes to the following software, firmware, and information: [Assignment: organization-defined software, firmware, and information]; and
 b. Take the following actions when unauthorized changes to the software, firmware, and information are detected: [Assignment: organization-defined actions].

SI-8.name: Spam Protection
SI-8.description:
a. Employ spam protection mechanisms at system entry and exit points to detect and act on unsolicited messages; and
 b. Update spam protection mechanisms when new releases are available in accordance with organizational configuration management policy and procedures.

SI-10.name: Information Input Validation
SI-10.description: Check the validity of the following information inputs: [Assignment: organization-defined information inputs to the system].

SI-11.name: Error Handling
SI-11.description:
a. Generate error messages that provide information necessary for corrective actions without revealing information that could be exploited; and
 b. Reveal error messages only to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles].

SI-12.name: Information Management and Retention
SI-12.description: Manage and retain information within the system and information output from the system in accordance with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, guidelines and operational requirements.

SI-13.name: Predictable Failure Prevention
SI-13.description:
a. Determine mean time to failure (MTTF) for the following system components in specific environments of operation: [Assignment: organization-defined system components]; and
 b. Provide substitute system components and a means to exchange active and standby components in accordance with the following criteria: [Assignment: organization-defined MTTF substitution criteria].

SI-14.name: Non-persistence
SI-14.description:
Implement non-persistent [Assignment: organization-defined system components and services] that are initiated in a known state and terminated [Selection (one or more): upon end of session of use; periodically at [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]
  ].

SI-15.name: Information Output Filtering
SI-15.description: Validate information output from the following software programs and/or applications to ensure that the information is consistent with the expected content: [Assignment: organization-defined software programs and/or applications].

SI-16.name: Memory Protection
SI-16.description: Implement the following controls to protect the system memory from unauthorized code execution: [Assignment: organization-defined controls].

SI-17.name: Fail-safe Procedures
SI-17.description: Implement the indicated fail-safe procedures when the indicated failures occur: [Assignment: organization-defined list of failure conditions and associated fail-safe procedures].

SI-18.name: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations
SI-18.description:
a. Check the accuracy, relevance, timeliness, and completeness of personally identifiable information across the information life cycle [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; and
 b. Correct or delete inaccurate or outdated personally identifiable information.

SI-19.name: De-identification
SI-19.description:
a. Remove the following elements of personally identifiable information from datasets: [Assignment: organization-defined elements of personally identifiable information]; and
 b. Evaluate [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] for effectiveness of de-identification.

SI-20.name: Tainting
SI-20.description: Embed data or capabilities in the following systems or system components to determine if organizational data has been exfiltrated or improperly removed from the organization: [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components].

SI-21.name: Information Refresh
SI-21.description: Refresh [Assignment: organization-defined information] at [Assignment: organization-defined frequencies] or generate the information on demand and delete the information when no longer needed.

SI-22.name: Information Diversity
SI-22.description:
a. Identify the following alternative sources of information for [Assignment: organization-defined essential functions and services]: [Assignment: organization-defined alternative information sources]; and
 b. Use an alternative information source for the execution of essential functions or services on [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components] when the primary source of information is corrupted or unavailable.

SI-23.name: Information Fragmentation
SI-23.description:
Based on [Assignment: organization-defined circumstances]:
 a. Fragment the following information: [Assignment: organization-defined information]; and
 b. Distribute the fragmented information across the following systems or system components: [Assignment: Assignment organization-defined systems or system components].

SR-1.name: Policy and Procedures
SR-1.description:
a. Develop, document, and disseminate to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]:
 1. [Selection (one or more): organization-level; mission/business process-level; system-level] supply chain risk management policy that:
 (a) Addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and
 (b) Is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; and
 2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the supply chain risk management policy and the associated supply chain risk management controls;
 b. Designate an [Assignment: organization-defined official] to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the supply chain risk management policy and procedures; and
 c. Review and update the current supply chain risk management:
 1. Policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events]; and
 2. Procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events].

SR-2.name: Supply Chain Risk Management Plan

SR-3.name: Supply Chain Controls and Processes

SR-4.name: Provenance
SR-4.description: Document, monitor, and maintain valid provenance of the following systems, system components, and associated data: [Assignment: organization-defined systems, system components, and associated data].

SR-5.name: Acquisition Strategies, Tools, and Methods
SR-5.description: Employ the following acquisition strategies, contract tools, and procurement methods to protect against, identify, and mitigate supply chain risks: [Assignment: organization-defined acquisition strategies, contract tools, and procurement methods].

SR-6.name: Supplier Assessments and Reviews
SR-6.description: Assess and review the supply chain-related risks associated with suppliers or contractors and the system, system component, or system service they provide [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].

SR-7.name: Supply Chain Operations Security
SR-7.description: Employ the following Operations Security (OPSEC) controls to protect supply chain-related information for the system, system component, or system service: [Assignment: organization-defined Operations Security (OPSEC) controls].

SR-8.name: Notification Agreements

SR-9.name: Tamper Resistance and Detection
SR-9.description: Implement a tamper protection program for the system, system component, or system service.

SR-10.name: Inspection of Systems or Components
SR-10.description:
Inspect the following systems or system components [Selection (one or more): at random; at [Assignment: organization-defined frequency], upon [Assignment: organization-defined indications of need for inspection]
  ] to detect tampering: [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components].

SR-11.name: Component Authenticity

SR-12.name: Component Disposal
SR-12.description: Dispose of [Assignment: organization-defined data, documentation, tools, or system components] using the following techniques and methods: [Assignment: organization-defined techniques and methods].

ISM-0027.name: System owners
ISM-0027.description: System owners obtain authorisation to operate each system from its authorising officer based on the acceptance of the security risks associated with its operation.

ISM-0039.name: Development and maintenance of security documentation
ISM-0039.description: A cyber security strategy is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0041.name: System-specific security documentation
ISM-0041.description: Systems have a system security plan that includes an overview of the system (covering the system’s purpose, the system boundary and how the system is managed) as well as an annex that covers applicable controls from this document and any additional controls that have been identified and implemented.

ISM-0042.name: System administration
ISM-0042.description: System administration processes, and supporting system administration procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0043.name: System-specific security documentation
ISM-0043.description:
Systems have a cyber security incident response plan that covers the following:
 • guidelines on what constitutes a cyber security incident
 • the types of cyber security incidents likely to be encountered and the expected response to each type
 • how to report cyber security incidents, internally to an organisation and externally to relevant authorities
 • other parties which need to be informed in the event of a cyber security incident
 • the authority, or authorities, responsible for investigating and responding to cyber security incidents
 • the criteria by which an investigation of a cyber security incident would be requested from a law enforcement agency, the Australian Signals Directorate or other relevant authority
 • the steps necessary to ensure the integrity of evidence relating to a cyber security incident
 • system contingency measures or a reference to such details if they are located in a separate document.

ISM-0047.name: Development and maintenance of security documentation
ISM-0047.description: Organisational-level security documentation is approved by the Chief Information Security Officer while system-specific security documentation is approved by the system’s authorising officer.

ISM-0072.name: Managed services and cloud services
ISM-0072.description: Security requirements associated with the confidentiality, integrity and availability of data are documented in contractual arrangements with service providers and reviewed on a regular and ongoing basis to ensure they remain fit for purpose.

ISM-0078.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0078.description: Systems processing, storing or communicating AUSTEO or AGAO data remain at all times under the control of an Australian national working for or on behalf of the Australian Government.

ISM-0100.name: Gateways
ISM-0100.description: Gateways undergo a security assessment by an IRAP assessor at least every 24 months.

ISM-0109.name: Event logging and monitoring
ISM-0109.description: Event logs from workstations are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

ISM-0120.name: Managing cyber security incidents
ISM-0120.description: Cyber security personnel have access to sufficient data sources and tools to ensure that systems can be monitored for key indicators of compromise.

ISM-0123.name: Managing cyber security incidents
ISM-0123.description: Cyber security incidents are reported to the Chief Information Security Officer, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

ISM-0125.name: Managing cyber security incidents
ISM-0125.description: A cyber security incident register is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0133.name: Responding to cyber security incidents
ISM-0133.description: When a data spill occurs, data owners are advised and access to the data is restricted.

ISM-0137.name: Responding to cyber security incidents
ISM-0137.description: Legal advice is sought before allowing intrusion activity to continue on a system for the purpose of collecting further data or evidence.

ISM-0138.name: Responding to cyber security incidents
ISM-0138.description:
The integrity of evidence gathered during an investigation is maintained by investigators:
 • recording all of their actions
 • maintaining a proper chain of custody
 • following all instructions provided by relevant law enforcement agencies.

ISM-0140.name: Managing cyber security incidents
ISM-0140.description: Cyber security incidents are reported to ASD as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

ISM-0141.name: Managed services and cloud services
ISM-0141.description: The requirement for service providers to report cyber security incidents to a designated point of contact as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered is documented in contractual arrangements with service providers.

ISM-0142.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0142.description: The compromise or suspected compromise of cryptographic equipment or associated keying material is reported to the Chief Information Security Officer, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after it occurs.

ISM-0161.name: IT equipment and media
ISM-0161.description: IT equipment and media are secured when not in use.

ISM-0164.name: Facilities and systems
ISM-0164.description: Unauthorised people are prevented from observing systems, in particular workstation displays and keyboards, within facilities.

ISM-0181.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0181.description: Cabling infrastructure is installed in accordance with relevant Australian Standards, as directed by the Australian Communications and Media Authority.

ISM-0187.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0187.description: SECRET cables, when bundled together or run in conduit, are run exclusively in their own individual cable bundle or conduit.

ISM-0194.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0194.description: In shared facilities, a visible smear of conduit glue is used to seal all plastic conduit joints and TOP SECRET conduits connected by threaded lock nuts.

ISM-0195.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0195.description: In shared facilities, uniquely identifiable SCEC-approved tamper-evident seals are used to seal all removable covers on TOP SECRET cable reticulation systems.

ISM-0198.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0198.description: When penetrating a TOP SECRET audio secure room, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation is consulted and all directions provided are complied with.

ISM-0201.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0201.description: Labels for TOP SECRET conduits are a minimum size of 2.5 cm x 1 cm, attached at five-metre intervals and marked as ‘TS RUN’.

ISM-0206.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0206.description: Cable labelling processes, and supporting cable labelling procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0208.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0208.description:
A cable register contains the following for each cable:
 • cable identifier
 • cable colour
 • sensitivity/classification
 • source
 • destination
 • location
 • seal numbers (if applicable).

ISM-0211.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0211.description: A cable register is developed, implemented, maintained and verified on a regular basis.

ISM-0213.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0213.description: SECRET and TOP SECRET cables are terminated on their own individual patch panels.

ISM-0216.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0216.description: TOP SECRET patch panels are installed in individual TOP SECRET cabinets.

ISM-0217.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0217.description:
Where spatial constraints demand non-TOP SECRET patch panels be installed in the same cabinet as a TOP SECRET patch panel:
 • a physical barrier in the cabinet is provided to separate patch panels
 • only personnel holding a Positive Vetting security clearance have access to the cabinet
 • approval from the TOP SECRET system’s authorising officer is obtained prior to installation.

ISM-0218.name: Cabling infrastructure
ISM-0218.description: If TOP SECRET fibre-optic fly leads exceeding five metres in length are used to connect wall outlet boxes to IT equipment, they are run in a protective and easily inspected pathway that is clearly labelled at the IT equipment end with the wall outlet box’s identifier.

ISM-0225.name: Facilities and systems
ISM-0225.description: Unauthorised RF and IR devices are not brought into SECRET and TOP SECRET areas.

ISM-0229.name: Telephone systems
ISM-0229.description: Personnel are advised of the permitted sensitivity or classification of information that can be discussed over internal and external telephone systems.

ISM-0230.name: Telephone systems
ISM-0230.description: Personnel are advised of security risks posed by non-secure telephone systems in areas where sensitive or classified conversations can occur.

ISM-0231.name: Telephone systems
ISM-0231.description: When using cryptographic equipment to permit different levels of conversation for different kinds of connections, telephone systems give a visual indication of what kind of connection has been made.

ISM-0232.name: Telephone systems
ISM-0232.description: Telephone systems used for sensitive or classified conversations encrypt all traffic that passes over external systems.

ISM-0233.name: Telephone systems
ISM-0233.description: Cordless telephone handsets and headsets are not used for sensitive or classified conversations unless all communications are encrypted.

ISM-0235.name: Telephone systems
ISM-0235.description: Speakerphones are not used on telephone systems in TOP SECRET areas unless the telephone system is located in an audio secure room, the room is audio secure during conversations and only personnel involved in conversations are present in the room.

ISM-0236.name: Telephone systems
ISM-0236.description: Off-hook audio protection features are used on telephone systems in areas where background conversations may exceed the sensitivity or classification that the telephone system is authorised for communicating.

ISM-0240.name: Mobile device usage
ISM-0240.description: Paging, Multimedia Message Service, Short Message Service and messaging apps are not used to communicate sensitive or classified data.

ISM-0241.name: Fax machines and multifunction devices
ISM-0241.description: When sending fax messages, the fax message is encrypted to an appropriate level to be communicated over unsecured telecommunications infrastructure.

ISM-0245.name: Fax machines and multifunction devices
ISM-0245.description: A direct connection from an MFD to a digital telephone system is not enabled unless the digital telephone system is authorised to operate at the same sensitivity or classification as the network to which the MFD is connected.

ISM-0246.name: Emanation security
ISM-0246.description: When an emanation security threat assessment is required, it is sought as early as possible in a system’s life cycle.

ISM-0248.name: Emanation security
ISM-0248.description: System owners deploying OFFICIAL: Sensitive or PROTECTED systems with radio frequency transmitters (including any wireless capabilities) that will be located within 20 meters of SECRET or TOP SECRET systems contact ASD for an emanation security threat assessment.

ISM-0249.name: Emanation security
ISM-0249.description: System owners deploying SECRET or TOP SECRET systems in mobile platforms, or as a deployable capability, contact ASD for an emanation security threat assessment.

ISM-0250.name: Emanation security
ISM-0250.description: IT equipment meets industry and government standards relating to electromagnetic interference/electromagnetic compatibility.

ISM-0252.name: Cyber security awareness training
ISM-0252.description:
Cyber security awareness training is undertaken annually by all personnel and covers:
 • the purpose of the cyber security awareness training
 • security appointments and contacts
 • authorised use of systems and their resources
 • protection of systems and their resources
 • reporting of cyber security incidents and suspected compromises of systems and their resources.

ISM-0258.name: Web proxies
ISM-0258.description: A web usage policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0260.name: Web proxies
ISM-0260.description: All web access, including that by internal servers, is conducted through web proxies.

ISM-0261.name: Web proxies
ISM-0261.description:
The following details are centrally logged for websites accessed via web proxies:
 • web address
 • date and time
 • user
 • amount of data uploaded and downloaded
 • internal and external IP addresses.

ISM-0263.name: Web content filters
ISM-0263.description: TLS traffic communicated through gateways is decrypted and inspected.

ISM-0264.name: Email usage
ISM-0264.description: An email usage policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0267.name: Email usage
ISM-0267.description: Access to non-approved webmail services is blocked.

ISM-0269.name: Email usage
ISM-0269.description: Emails containing Australian Eyes Only, Australian Government Access Only or Releasable To data are not sent to email distribution lists unless the nationality of all members of email distribution lists can be confirmed.

ISM-0270.name: Email usage
ISM-0270.description: Protective markings are applied to emails and reflect the highest sensitivity or classification of the subject, body and attachments.

ISM-0271.name: Email usage
ISM-0271.description: Protective marking tools do not automatically insert protective markings into emails.

ISM-0272.name: Email usage
ISM-0272.description: Protective marking tools do not allow users to select protective markings that a system has not been authorised to process, store or communicate.

ISM-0280.name: Evaluated product procurement
ISM-0280.description: If procuring an evaluated product, a product that has completed a PP-based evaluation, including against all applicable PP modules, is selected in preference to one that has completed an EAL-based evaluation.

ISM-0285.name: Evaluated product procurement
ISM-0285.description: Evaluated products are delivered in a manner consistent with any delivery procedures defined in associated evaluation documentation.

ISM-0286.name: Evaluated product procurement
ISM-0286.description: When procuring high assurance information technology (IT) equipment, ASD is contacted for any equipment-specific delivery procedures.

ISM-0289.name: Evaluated product usage
ISM-0289.description: Evaluated products are installed, configured, administered and operated in an evaluated configuration and in accordance with vendor guidance.

ISM-0290.name: Evaluated product usage
ISM-0290.description: High assurance IT equipment is installed, configured, administered and operated in an evaluated configuration and in accordance with ASD guidance.

ISM-0293.name: IT equipment usage
ISM-0293.description: IT equipment is classified based on the highest sensitivity or classification of data that it is approved for processing, storing or communicating.

ISM-0294.name: IT equipment usage
ISM-0294.description: IT equipment, with the exception of high assurance IT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

ISM-0296.name: IT equipment usage
ISM-0296.description: ASD’s approval is sought before applying labels to external surfaces of high assurance IT equipment.

ISM-0298.name: System patching
ISM-0298.description: A centralised and managed approach that maintains the integrity of patches or updates, and confirms that they have been applied successfully, is used to patch or update applications, operating systems, drivers and firmware.

ISM-0300.name: System patching
ISM-0300.description: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in high assurance IT equipment are applied only when approved by ASD, and in doing so, using methods and timeframes prescribed by ASD.

ISM-0304.name: System patching
ISM-0304.description: Applications other than office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF software, Adobe Flash Player, and security products that are no longer supported by vendors are removed.

ISM-0305.name: IT equipment maintenance and repairs
ISM-0305.description: Maintenance and repairs of IT equipment is carried out on site by an appropriately cleared technician.

ISM-0306.name: IT equipment maintenance and repairs
ISM-0306.description:
If an appropriately cleared technician is not used to undertake maintenance or repairs of IT equipment, the technician is escorted by someone who:
 • is appropriately cleared and briefed
 • takes due care to ensure that data is not disclosed
 • takes all responsible measures to ensure the integrity of the IT equipment
 • has the authority to direct the technician
 • is sufficiently familiar with the IT equipment to understand the work being performed.

ISM-0307.name: IT equipment maintenance and repairs
ISM-0307.description: If an appropriately cleared technician is not used to undertake maintenance or repairs of IT equipment, the IT equipment and associated media is sanitised before maintenance or repair work is undertaken.

ISM-0310.name: IT equipment maintenance and repairs
ISM-0310.description: IT equipment maintained or repaired off site is done so at facilities approved for handling the sensitivity or classification of the IT equipment.

ISM-0311.name: IT equipment sanitisation and destruction
ISM-0311.description: IT equipment containing media is sanitised by removing the media from the IT equipment or by sanitising the media in situ.

ISM-0312.name: IT equipment sanitisation and destruction
ISM-0312.description: IT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed, stored or communicated AUSTEO or AGAO data that cannot be sanitised in situ, is returned to Australia for destruction.

ISM-0313.name: IT equipment sanitisation and destruction
ISM-0313.description: IT equipment sanitisation processes, and supporting IT equipment sanitisation procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0315.name: IT equipment sanitisation and destruction
ISM-0315.description: High assurance IT equipment is destroyed prior to its disposal.

ISM-0316.name: IT equipment disposal
ISM-0316.description: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to release IT equipment, or its waste, into the public domain.

ISM-0317.name: IT equipment sanitisation and destruction
ISM-0317.description: At least three pages of random text with no blank areas are printed on each colour printer cartridge or MFD print drum.

ISM-0318.name: IT equipment sanitisation and destruction
ISM-0318.description: When unable to sanitise printer cartridges or MFD print drums, they are destroyed as per electrostatic memory devices.

ISM-0321.name: IT equipment disposal
ISM-0321.description: When disposing of IT equipment that has been designed or modified to meet emanation security standards, ASD is contacted for requirements relating to its disposal.

ISM-0323.name: Media usage
ISM-0323.description: Media is classified to the highest sensitivity or classification of data it stores, unless the media has been classified to a higher sensitivity or classification.

ISM-0325.name: Media usage
ISM-0325.description: Any media connected to a system with a higher sensitivity or classification than the media is reclassified to the higher sensitivity or classification, unless the media is read-only or the system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be ensured.

ISM-0330.name: Media usage
ISM-0330.description: Before reclassifying media to a lower sensitivity or classification, the media is sanitised or destroyed, and a formal administrative decision is made to reclassify it.

ISM-0332.name: Media usage
ISM-0332.description: Media, with the exception of internally mounted fixed media within information technology equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

ISM-0336.name: IT equipment usage
ISM-0336.description: A networked IT equipment register is developed, implemented, maintained and verified on a regular basis.

ISM-0337.name: Media usage
ISM-0337.description: Media is only used with systems that are authorised to process, store or communicate its sensitivity or classification.

ISM-0341.name: Operating system hardening
ISM-0341.description: Automatic execution features for removable media are disabled.

ISM-0343.name: Operating system hardening
ISM-0343.description: If there is no business requirement for writing to removable media and devices, such functionality is disabled via the use of device access control software or by disabling external communication interfaces.

ISM-0345.name: Operating system hardening
ISM-0345.description: External communication interfaces that allow DMA are disabled.

ISM-0347.name: Media usage
ISM-0347.description: When transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, write-once media is used unless the destination system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be ensured.

ISM-0348.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0348.description: Media sanitisation processes, and supporting media sanitisation procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0350.name: Media destruction
ISM-0350.description:
The following media types are destroyed prior to their disposal:
 • microfiche and microfilm
 • optical discs
 • programmable read-only memory
 • read-only memory
 • other types of media that cannot be sanitised.

ISM-0351.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0351.description: Volatile media is sanitised by removing its power for at least 10 minutes.

ISM-0352.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0352.description: SECRET and TOP SECRET volatile media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

ISM-0354.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0354.description: Non-volatile magnetic media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once (or three times if pre-2001 or under 15 GB) in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

ISM-0356.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0356.description: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile magnetic media retains its classification.

ISM-0357.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0357.description: Non-volatile EPROM media is sanitised by applying three times the manufacturer’s specified ultraviolet erasure time and then overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

ISM-0358.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0358.description: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile EPROM and EEPROM media retains its classification.

ISM-0359.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0359.description: Non-volatile flash memory media is sanitised by overwriting it at least twice in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

ISM-0360.name: Media sanitisation
ISM-0360.description: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile flash memory media retains its classification.

ISM-0361.name: Media destruction
ISM-0361.description: Magnetic media is destroyed using a degausser with a suitable magnetic field strength and magnetic orientation.

ISM-0362.name: Media destruction
ISM-0362.description: Product-specific directions provided by degausser manufacturers are followed.

ISM-0363.name: Media destruction
ISM-0363.description: Media destruction processes, and supporting media destruction procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0368.name: Media destruction
ISM-0368.description: Media destroyed using a hammer mill, disintegrator, grinder/sander or by cutting results in media waste particles no larger than 9 mm.

ISM-0370.name: Media destruction
ISM-0370.description: The destruction of media is performed under the supervision of at least one cleared person.

ISM-0371.name: Media destruction
ISM-0371.description: Personnel supervising the destruction of media supervise its handling to the point of destruction and ensure that the destruction is completed successfully.

ISM-0372.name: Media destruction
ISM-0372.description: The destruction of media storing accountable material is performed under the supervision of at least two cleared personnel.

ISM-0373.name: Media destruction
ISM-0373.description: Personnel supervising the destruction of media storing accountable material supervise its handling to the point of destruction, ensure that the destruction is completed successfully and sign a destruction certificate afterwards.

ISM-0374.name: Media disposal
ISM-0374.description: Media disposal processes, and supporting media disposal procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0375.name: Media disposal
ISM-0375.description: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to release media, or its waste, into the public domain.

ISM-0378.name: Media disposal
ISM-0378.description: Labels and markings indicating the owner, sensitivity, classification or any other marking that can associate media with its prior use are removed prior to its disposal.

ISM-0380.name: Operating system hardening
ISM-0380.description: Unneeded accounts, components, services and functionality of operating systems are disabled or removed.

ISM-0382.name: Operating system hardening
ISM-0382.description: Unprivileged users do not have the ability to uninstall or disable approved software.

ISM-0383.name: Operating system hardening
ISM-0383.description: Default accounts or credentials for operating systems, including for any pre-configured accounts, are changed.

ISM-0385.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0385.description: Servers maintain effective functional separation with other servers allowing them to operate independently.

ISM-0393.name: Databases
ISM-0393.description: Databases and their contents are classified based on the sensitivity or classification of data that they contain.

ISM-0400.name: Application development
ISM-0400.description: Development, testing and production environments are segregated.

ISM-0401.name: Application development
ISM-0401.description: Secure-by-design and secure-by-default principles, use of memory-safe programming languages where possible, and secure programming practices are used as part of application development.

ISM-0402.name: Application development
ISM-0402.description: Applications are comprehensively tested for vulnerabilities, using static application security testing and dynamic application security testing, prior to their initial release and any subsequent releases.

ISM-0405.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0405.description: Requests for unprivileged access to systems, applications and data repositories are validated when first requested.

ISM-0407.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0407.description:
A secure record is maintained for the life of each system covering the following for each user:
 • their user identification
 • their signed agreement to abide by usage policies for the system and its resources
 • who provided authorisation for their access
 • when their access was granted
 • the level of access that they were granted
 • when their access, and their level of access, was last reviewed
 • when their level of access was changed, and to what extent (if applicable)
 • when their access was withdrawn (if applicable).

ISM-0408.name: Authentication hardening
ISM-0408.description: Systems have a logon banner that reminds users of their security responsibilities when accessing the system and its resources.

ISM-0409.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0409.description: Foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, do not have access to systems that process, store or communicate AUSTEO or REL data unless effective controls are in place to ensure such data is not accessible to them.

ISM-0411.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0411.description: Foreign nationals, excluding seconded foreign nationals, do not have access to systems that process, store or communicate AGAO data unless effective controls are in place to ensure such data is not accessible to them.

ISM-0414.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0414.description: Personnel granted access to a system and its resources are uniquely identifiable.

ISM-0415.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0415.description: The use of shared user accounts is strictly controlled, and personnel using such accounts are uniquely identifiable.

ISM-0417.name: Authentication hardening
ISM-0417.description: When systems cannot support multi-factor authentication, single-factor authentication using passphrases is implemented instead.

ISM-0418.name: Authentication hardening
ISM-0418.description: Credentials are kept separate from systems they are used to authenticate to, except for when performing authentication activities.

ISM-0420.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0420.description: Where a system processes, stores or communicates AUSTEO, AGAO or REL data, personnel who are foreign nationals are identified as such, including by their specific nationality.

ISM-0421.name: Authentication hardening
ISM-0421.description: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication are at least 4 random words with a total minimum length of 14 characters, unless more stringent requirements apply.

ISM-0422.name: Authentication hardening
ISM-0422.description: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication on TOP SECRET systems are at least 6 random words with a total minimum length of 20 characters.

ISM-0428.name: Authentication hardening
ISM-0428.description:
Systems are configured with a session or screen lock that:
 • activates after a maximum of 15 minutes of user inactivity, or if manually activated by users
 • conceals all session content on the screen
 • ensures that the screen does not enter a power saving state before the session or screen lock is activated
 • requires users to authenticate to unlock the session
 • denies users the ability to disable the session or screen locking mechanism.

ISM-0430.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0430.description: Access to systems, applications and data repositories is removed or suspended on the same day personnel no longer have a legitimate requirement for access.

ISM-0432.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0432.description: Access requirements for a system and its resources are documented in its system security plan.

ISM-0434.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0434.description: Personnel undergo appropriate employment screening and, where necessary, hold an appropriate security clearance before being granted access to a system and its resources.

ISM-0435.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0435.description: Personnel receive any necessary briefings before being granted access to a system and its resources.

ISM-0441.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0441.description: When personnel are granted temporary access to a system, effective controls are put in place to restrict their access to only data required for them to undertake their duties.

ISM-0443.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0443.description: Temporary access is not granted to systems that process, store or communicate caveated or sensitive compartmented information.

ISM-0445.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0445.description: Privileged users are assigned a dedicated privileged account to be used solely for duties requiring privileged access.

ISM-0446.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0446.description: Foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, do not have privileged access to systems that process, store or communicate AUSTEO or REL data.

ISM-0447.name: Access to systems and their resources
ISM-0447.description: Foreign nationals, excluding seconded foreign nationals, do not have privileged access to systems that process, store or communicate AGAO data.

ISM-0455.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0455.description: Where practical, cryptographic equipment and software provides a means of data recovery to allow for circumstances where the encryption key is unavailable due to loss, damage or failure.

ISM-0457.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0457.description: Cryptographic equipment or software that has completed a Common Criteria evaluation against a Protection Profile is used when encrypting media that contains OFFICIAL: Sensitive or PROTECTED data.

ISM-0459.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0459.description: Full disk encryption, or partial encryption where access controls will only allow writing to the encrypted partition, is implemented when encrypting data at rest.

ISM-0460.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0460.description: HACE is used when encrypting media that contains SECRET or TOP SECRET data.

ISM-0462.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0462.description: When a user authenticates to the encryption functionality of IT equipment or media, it is treated in accordance with its original sensitivity or classification until the user deauthenticates from the encryption functionality.

ISM-0465.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0465.description: Cryptographic equipment or software that has completed a Common Criteria evaluation against a Protection Profile is used to protect OFFICIAL: Sensitive or PROTECTED data when communicated over insufficiently secure networks, outside of appropriately secure areas or via public network infrastructure.

ISM-0467.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0467.description: HACE is used to protect SECRET and TOP SECRET data when communicated over insufficiently secure networks, outside of appropriately secure areas or via public network infrastructure.

ISM-0469.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0469.description: An ASD-Approved Cryptographic Protocol (AACP) or high assurance cryptographic protocol is used to protect data when communicated over network infrastructure.

ISM-0471.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
ISM-0471.description: Only AACAs or high assurance cryptographic algorithms are used by cryptographic equipment and software.

ISM-0472.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
ISM-0472.description: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus of at least 2048 bits is used, preferably 3072 bits.

ISM-0474.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
ISM-0474.description: When using ECDH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a base point order and key size of at least 224 bits is used, preferably the NIST P-384 curve.

ISM-0475.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
ISM-0475.description: When using ECDSA for digital signatures, a base point order and key size of at least 224 bits is used, preferably the P-384 curve.

ISM-0476.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
ISM-0476.description: When using RSA for digital signatures, and passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a modulus of at least 2048 bits is used, preferably 3072 bits.

ISM-0477.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
ISM-0477.description: When using RSA for digital signatures, and for passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a different key pair is used for digital signatures and passing encrypted session keys.

ISM-0479.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
ISM-0479.description: Symmetric cryptographic algorithms are not used in Electronic Codebook Mode.

ISM-0481.name: ASD-Approved Cryptographic Protocols
ISM-0481.description: Only AACPs or high assurance cryptographic protocols are used by cryptographic equipment and software.

ISM-0484.name: Secure Shell
ISM-0484.description:
The SSH daemon is configured to:
 • only listen on the required interfaces (ListenAddress xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx)
 • have a suitable login banner (Banner x)
 • have a login authentication timeout of no more than 60 seconds (LoginGraceTime 60)
 • disable host-based authentication (HostbasedAuthentication no)
 • disable rhosts-based authentication (IgnoreRhosts yes)
 • disable the ability to login directly as root (PermitRootLogin no)
 • disable empty passwords (PermitEmptyPasswords no)
 • disable connection forwarding (AllowTCPForwarding no)
 • disable gateway ports (GatewayPorts no)
 • disable X11 forwarding (X11Forwarding no).

ISM-0485.name: Secure Shell
ISM-0485.description: Public key-based authentication is used for SSH connections.

ISM-0487.name: Secure Shell
ISM-0487.description:
When using logins without a passphrase for SSH connections, the following are disabled:
 • access from IP addresses that do not require access
 • port forwarding
 • agent credential forwarding
 • X11 display remoting
 • console access.

ISM-0488.name: Secure Shell
ISM-0488.description: If using remote access without the use of a passphrase for SSH connections, the ‘forced command’ option is used to specify what command is executed and parameter checking is enabled.

ISM-0489.name: Secure Shell
ISM-0489.description: When SSH-agent or similar key caching programs are used, it is limited to workstations and servers with screen locks and key caches that are set to expire within four hours of inactivity.

ISM-0490.name: Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extension
ISM-0490.description: Versions of S/MIME earlier than S/MIME version 3.0 are not used for S/MIME connections.

ISM-0494.name: Internet Protocol Security
ISM-0494.description: Tunnel mode is used for IPsec connections; however, if using transport mode, an IP tunnel is used.

ISM-0496.name: Internet Protocol Security
ISM-0496.description: The ESP protocol is used for authentication and encryption of IPsec connections.

ISM-0498.name: Internet Protocol Security
ISM-0498.description: A security association lifetime of less than four hours (14400 seconds) is used for IPsec connections.

ISM-0499.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0499.description: Communications security doctrine produced by ASD for the management and operation of HACE is complied with.

ISM-0501.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0501.description: Keyed cryptographic equipment is transported based on the sensitivity or classification of its keying material.

ISM-0507.name: Cryptographic fundamentals
ISM-0507.description: Cryptographic key management processes, and supporting cryptographic key management procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0516.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0516.description: Network documentation includes high-level network diagrams showing all connections into networks and logical network diagrams showing all critical servers, high-value servers, network devices and network security appliances.

ISM-0518.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0518.description: Network documentation is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0520.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0520.description: Network access controls are implemented on networks to prevent the connection of unauthorised network devices and other IT equipment.

ISM-0521.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0521.description: IPv6 functionality is disabled in dual-stack network devices unless it is being used.

ISM-0529.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0529.description: VLANs are not used to separate network traffic between networks belonging to different security domains.

ISM-0530.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0530.description: Network devices managing VLANs are administered from the most trusted security domain.

ISM-0534.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0534.description: Unused physical ports on network devices are disabled.

ISM-0535.name: Network design and configuration
ISM-0535.description: Network devices managing VLANs belonging to different security domains do not share VLAN trunks.

ISM-0536.name: Wireless networks
ISM-0536.description: Public wireless networks provided for general public use are segregated from all other organisation networks.

ISM-0546.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0546.description: When video conferencing or IP telephony traffic passes through a gateway containing a firewall or proxy, a video-aware or voice-aware firewall or proxy is used.

ISM-0547.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0547.description: Video conferencing and IP telephony calls are conducted using a secure real-time transport protocol.

ISM-0548.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0548.description: Video conferencing and IP telephony calls are established using a secure session initiation protocol.

ISM-0549.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0549.description: Video conferencing and IP telephony traffic is separated physically or logically from other data traffic.

ISM-0551.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0551.description:
IP telephony is configured such that:
 • IP phones authenticate themselves to the call controller upon registration
 • auto-registration is disabled and only authorised devices are allowed to access the network
 • unauthorised devices are blocked by default
 • all unused and prohibited functionality is disabled.

ISM-0553.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0553.description: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on a video conferencing network, including call setup and changing settings.

ISM-0554.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0554.description: An encrypted and non-replayable two-way authentication scheme is used for call authentication and authorisation.

ISM-0555.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0555.description: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on an IP telephony network, including registering a new IP phone, changing phone users, changing settings and accessing voicemail.

ISM-0556.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0556.description: Workstations are not connected to video conferencing units or IP phones unless the workstation or the device uses Virtual Local Area Networks or similar mechanisms to maintain separation between video conferencing, IP telephony and other data traffic.

ISM-0558.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0558.description: IP phones used in public areas do not have the ability to access data networks, voicemail and directory services.

ISM-0559.name: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony
ISM-0559.description: Microphones (including headsets and USB handsets) and webcams are not used with non-SECRET workstations in SECRET areas.

ISM-0565.name: Email usage
ISM-0565.description: Email servers are configured to block, log and report emails with inappropriate protective markings.

ISM-0567.name: Email gateways and servers
ISM-0567.description: Email servers only relay emails destined for or originating from their domains (including subdomains).

ISM-0569.name: Email gateways and servers
ISM-0569.description: Emails are routed via centralised email gateways.

ISM-0570.name: Email gateways and servers
ISM-0570.description: Where backup or alternative email gateways are in place, they are maintained at the same standard as the primary email gateway.

ISM-0571.name: Email gateways and servers
ISM-0571.description: When users send or receive emails, an authenticated and encrypted channel is used to route emails via their organisation’s centralised email gateways.

ISM-0572.name: Email gateways and servers
ISM-0572.description: Opportunistic TLS encryption is enabled on email servers that make incoming or outgoing email connections over public network infrastructure.

ISM-0574.name: Email gateways and servers
ISM-0574.description: SPF is used to specify authorised email servers (or lack thereof) for an organisation’s domains (including subdomains).

ISM-0576.name: Managing cyber security incidents
ISM-0576.description: A cyber security incident management policy, and associated cyber security incident response plan, is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0580.name: Event logging and monitoring
ISM-0580.description: An event logging policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0582.name: Operating system hardening
ISM-0582.description:
The following events are centrally logged for operating systems:
 • application and operating system crashes and error messages
 • changes to security policies and system configurations
 • successful user logons and logoffs, failed user logons and account lockouts
 • failures, restarts and changes to important processes and services
 • requests to access internet resources
 • security product-related events
 • system startups and shutdowns.

ISM-0585.name: Event logging and monitoring
ISM-0585.description: For each event logged, the date and time of the event, the relevant user or process, the relevant filename, the event description, and the information technology equipment involved are recorded.

ISM-0588.name: Fax machines and multifunction devices
ISM-0588.description: A fax machine and MFD usage policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0589.name: Fax machines and multifunction devices
ISM-0589.description: MFDs are not used to scan or copy documents above the sensitivity or classification of networks they are connected to.

ISM-0590.name: Fax machines and multifunction devices
ISM-0590.description: Authentication measures for MFDs are the same strength as those used for workstations on networks they are connected to.

ISM-0591.name: Peripheral switches
ISM-0591.description: Evaluated peripheral switches are used when sharing peripherals between systems.

ISM-0597.name: Cross Domain Solutions
ISM-0597.description: When planning, designing, implementing or introducing additional connectivity to CDSs, ASD is consulted and any directions provided by ASD are complied with.

ISM-0610.name: Cross Domain Solutions
ISM-0610.description: Users are trained on the secure use of CDSs before access is granted.

ISM-0611.name: Gateways
ISM-0611.description: System administrators for gateways are assigned the minimum privileges required to perform their duties.

ISM-0612.name: Gateways
ISM-0612.description: System administrators for gateways are formally trained on the operation and management of gateways.

ISM-0613.name: Gateways
ISM-0613.description: System administrators for gateways that connect to Australian Eyes Only or Releasable To networks are Australian nationals.

ISM-0616.name: Gateways
ISM-0616.description: Separation of duties is implemented in performing administrative activities for gateways.

ISM-0619.name: Gateways
ISM-0619.description: Users authenticate to other networks accessed via gateways.

ISM-0622.name: Gateways
ISM-0622.description: IT equipment authenticates to other networks accessed via gateways.

ISM-0626.name: Cross Domain Solutions
ISM-0626.description: CDSs are implemented between SECRET or TOP SECRET networks and any other networks belonging to different security domains.

ISM-0628.name: Gateways
ISM-0628.description: Gateways are implemented between networks belonging to different security domains.

ISM-0629.name: Gateways
ISM-0629.description: For gateways between networks belonging to different security domains, any shared components are managed by system administrators for the higher security domain or by system administrators from a mutually agreed upon third party.

ISM-0631.name: Gateways
ISM-0631.description: Gateways only allow explicitly authorised data flows.

ISM-0634.name: Gateways
ISM-0634.description:
The following events are centrally logged for gateways:
 • data packets and data flows permitted through gateways
 • data packets and data flows attempting to leave gateways
 • real-time alerts for attempted intrusions.

ISM-0635.name: Cross Domain Solutions
ISM-0635.description: CDSs implement isolated upward and downward network paths.

ISM-0637.name: Gateways
ISM-0637.description: Gateways implement a demilitarised zone if external parties require access to an organisation’s services.

ISM-0639.name: Firewalls
ISM-0639.description: Evaluated firewalls are used between networks belonging to different security domains.

ISM-0643.name: Diodes
ISM-0643.description: Evaluated diodes are used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between an organisation’s networks and public network infrastructure.

ISM-0645.name: Diodes
ISM-0645.description: Evaluated diodes used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between SECRET or TOP SECRET networks and public network infrastructure complete a high assurance evaluation.

ISM-0649.name: Content filtering
ISM-0649.description: Files imported or exported via gateways or CDSs are filtered for allowed file types.

ISM-0651.name: Content filtering
ISM-0651.description: Files identified by content filtering checks as malicious, or that cannot be inspected, are blocked.

ISM-0652.name: Content filtering
ISM-0652.description: Files identified by content filtering checks as suspicious are quarantined until reviewed and subsequently approved or not approved for release.

ISM-0657.name: Data transfers
ISM-0657.description: When manually importing data to systems, the data is scanned for malicious and active content.

ISM-0659.name: Content filtering
ISM-0659.description: Files imported or exported via gateways or CDSs undergo content filtering checks.

ISM-0660.name: Data transfers
ISM-0660.description: Data transfer logs for SECRET and TOP SECRET systems are fully verified at least monthly.

ISM-0661.name: Data transfers
ISM-0661.description: Users transferring data to and from systems are held accountable for data transfers they perform.

ISM-0663.name: Data transfers
ISM-0663.description: Data transfer processes, and supporting data transfer procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0664.name: Data transfers
ISM-0664.description: Data exported from SECRET and TOP SECRET systems is reviewed and authorised by a trusted source beforehand.

ISM-0665.name: Data transfers
ISM-0665.description: Trusted sources for SECRET and TOP SECRET systems are limited to people and services that have been authorised as such by the Chief Information Security Officer.

ISM-0669.name: Data transfers
ISM-0669.description: When manually exporting data from SECRET and TOP SECRET systems, digital signatures are validated and keyword checks are performed within all textual data.

ISM-0670.name: Cross Domain Solutions
ISM-0670.description: All security-relevant events generated by CDSs are centrally logged.

ISM-0675.name: Data transfers
ISM-0675.description: Data authorised for export from SECRET and TOP SECRET systems is digitally signed by a trusted source.

ISM-0677.name: Content filtering
ISM-0677.description: Files imported or exported via gateways or CDSs that have a digital signature or cryptographic checksum are validated.

ISM-0682.name: Mobile device usage
ISM-0682.description: Bluetooth functionality is not enabled on SECRET and TOP SECRET mobile devices.

ISM-0687.name: Mobile device management
ISM-0687.description: Mobile devices that access SECRET or TOP SECRET systems or data use mobile platforms that have been issued an Approval for Use by ASD and are operated in accordance with the latest version of their associated Australian Communications Security Instruction.

ISM-0694.name: Enterprise mobility
ISM-0694.description: Privately-owned mobile devices and desktop computers do not access SECRET and TOP SECRET systems or data.

ISM-0701.name: Mobile device usage
ISM-0701.description: Mobile device emergency sanitisation processes, and supporting mobile device emergency sanitisation procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

ISM-0702.name: Mobile device usage
ISM-0702.description: If a cryptographic zeroise or sanitise function is provided for cryptographic keys on a SECRET or TOP SECRET mobile device, the function is used as part of mobile device emergency sanitisation processes and procedures.

ISM-0705.name: Enterprise mobility
ISM-0705.description: When accessing an organisation’s network via a VPN connection, split tunnelling is disabled.

ISM-0714.name: Chief Information Security Officer
ISM-0714.description: A CISO is appointed to provide cyber security leadership and guidance for their organisation (covering information technology and operational technology).

ISM-0717.name: Chief Information Security Officer
ISM-0717.description: The CISO oversees the management of cyber security personnel within their organisation.

ISM-0718.name: Chief Information Security Officer
ISM-0718.description: The CISO regularly reports directly to their organisation’s executive committee or board of directors on cyber security matters.

ISM-0720.name: Chief Information Security Officer
ISM-0720.description: The CISO oversees the development, implementation and maintenance of a cyber security communications strategy to assist in communicating the cyber security vision and strategy for their organisation.

ISM-0724.name: Chief Information Security Officer
